report_title: US Fish and Seafood Wholesale Industry Report
executive_summary: The US Fish and seafood Wholesale industry has undergone considerable changes in recent years, influenced by shifting consumer preferences, technological advancements and global market dynamics. As an essential intermediary between seafood producers and retailers, wholesalers have faced increasing pressure to adapt to emerging trends. Despite these challenges, the industry remains a stable contributor to the US economy, though its growth has slowed due to market saturation.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Prices and Strong Consumer Taste Maintain Wholesalers Afloat
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Foodservice and drinking establishments and grocery retailers serve as the two primary distribution channels for the seafood industry's products, with revenue expected to rise 0.6% to $24.6 billion in 2024 and industry profit at 2.3% of revenue. Over the past five years, the industry has navigated rising demand for sustainability, alternative seafood products and global competition.

Restaurants impact the market by attracting wealthier patrons for premium seafood dishes. Retail seafood prices are rising, transferring costs to consumers who continue buying more through supermarkets. Consumers are shifting purchases from restaurants to grocery stores due to rising retail prices and sustained seafood demand.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Sustainability Shifts From Niche to Necessity
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers prioritize sustainably sourced seafood, pushing wholesalers to adapt practices. Certifications like MSC ensure consumer trust and market access. Stricter environmental regulations force sustainable practices. Companies embracing sustainability see brand loyalty and better positioning.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Downstream Markets Avoiding Wholesalers Are Chasing Away Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Vertically integrated manufacturers distribute products directly, bypassing wholesalers and shifting demand away from them. This trend particularly hurts smaller merchant wholesalers through increased competition and declining demand, forcing some to exit the industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Regulatory Changes Set a New Benchmark for the Seafood Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Increased food safety regulations substantially impacted fish and seafood wholesalers, necessitating enhanced quality control, processing methods and distribution protocols. Wholesalers invest in traceability systems to ensure authenticity, prevent counterfeiting and boost customer trust, making supply chains more transparent.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Wholesalers Embrace Eco-Friendly Practices Amid Rising Demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Rising consumer demand for sustainable seafood compels wholesalers to implement eco-friendly practices. Stricter environmental laws require sustainable sourcing and transparent supply chains. More wholesalers adopt certifications like MSC to meet sustainability expectations and regulations. Innovative technologies support sustainable fishing and minimize environmental impact.

Research highlights health benefits of fish and omega-3s, promoting healthier dietary choices. Evidence encourages consumers to incorporate more fish and seafood for heart health, brain function and overall well-being. Reports on risks of high meat consumption further bolster demand for fish and seafood.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry Seascape Is Evolving and Expanding
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Major wholesalers plan acquisitions to expand market share and reach, positioning them as dominant players. Consolidation in downstream retail makes national wholesalers attractive to food service and grocery chains. The gap between large and small wholesalers is expected to widen, with smaller ones focusing on niche markets.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Adapting Seafood Sourcing Strategies Amidst Global Changes Requires Shifting Channels
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Climate change may make some species less available in certain regions, requiring wholesalers to adapt sourcing strategies. Diversifying suppliers, exploring new markets and investing in aquaculture ensure supply resilience. Building supplier relationships in climate-resilient areas promotes sustainable practices and ecosystem conservation.

industry_definition: Establishments in this industry primarily wholesale fish and seafood; canned or packaged frozen products are excluded from the industry. This industry does not include manufacturers' sales branches and offices (MSBOs) where the wholesaling and preparation of seafood products occur as one undifferentiated operation; revenue from such MSBO's are included under the scope of the Seafood Preparation industry (IBISWorld 31171).

opportunities: Demand from food services and drinking places

key_trends: The primary competing industries include beef, pork, egg and poultry wholesaling. Each of these commodities offers a good substitute for protein found in seafood.
General line grocery merchant wholesalers are a significant source of external competition. They move a sizeable portion of seafood each year.
The amount of seafood being consumed is rising. This is because it presents a healthy substitute for red meat and poultry.
The price of seafood is increasing, boosting revenue figures. However, if wholesalers cannot pass on the price increase, profit may suffer.
Bumble Bee Foods is the only company that consists of 5.0% of the market by offering a wide variety of seafood products at competitive prices.
The Federal Drug Administration regulates storage and manufacturing quality to protect consumer health.
The government promotes seafood consumption as a healthy substitute for red meat.
The industry is labor-intensive, requiring significant human resources throughout the supply chain.
Current economic conditions have decreased disposable income, significantly declining expensive seafood consumption.
Seafood wholesalers locate near water sources and processing locations to facilitate fresh transportation.
Consumers prefer fresh shellfish and finfish over frozen meals, especially as income rises. Dining out at restaurants, hotels and food services is becoming more popular.
Demand from food services and drinking places impacts wholesaler revenue when it rises.
Per capita seafood consumption, influenced by perceived health benefits, affects downstream demand for fish products and wholesale demand.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The market encompasses a range of wholesale sectors, such as grocery wholesalers, frozen food wholesalers and those specifically dealing in fish and seafood. The decline in wholesale industries is primarily due to larger, vertically integrated companies. These companies have reduced operating costs and offered lower prices to retailers and food service providers, eliminating the need for middlemen.

The market segment is quite diverse, encompassing establishments from high-end seafood restaurants to more economical roadside diners and also includes hotels, food services and contract feeding services. Revenue within this segment has seen substantial growth because of a boost in consumer spending, which rebounded from recessionary lows and led to more people dining out.

The market comprises fish and seafood markets alongside specialty food stores, catering to a niche but growing segment of consumers with specific culinary preferences. The segment's revenue demonstrates promising growth potential, primarily driven by heightened demand from fish and seafood markets, which could result in increased sales and a significantly more robust revenue stream.

Other markets for fish and seafood wholesalers encompass a wide range of clients, including international customers, manufacturers that incorporate fish and seafood as production inputs, businesses using these products in their operations and households and individual consumers. Revenue from this specific business segment is expected to drop, resulting from falling demand for seafood preparation services, negatively impacting overall profitability.

products_and_services.product_description: Fresh finfish include many species that lack shells, featuring well-known options like salmon and bass and less common varieties such as carp. This diverse category caters to a broad consumer base.

Fresh shellfish encompasses a variety of species, including lobsters, crabs, scallops, shrimp, oysters, clams and other similar creatures, making it a diverse and sought-after category in the seafood market.

Industry products in this segment do not include packaged or processed items like frozen fish, seafood, precooked and peeled shrimp, microwaveable fish sticks, or fish patties. These non-perishable and storable foods are distinctly separate from fresh offerings.

Curing meat involves subjecting it to processes that preserve and extend its edibility and flavor. Standard curing methods for fish and seafood include smoking, drying and salting. This preservation technique ensures longevity while enhancing taste.

tier_1_suppliers: Fish & Seafood Aquaculture in the US
Truck & Bus Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Commercial Building Construction in the US
Woodworking Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Fish & Seafood Markets in the US
tier_2_buyers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US
Specialty Food Stores in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Food service establishments, such as full-service restaurants, cafeterias and fast-food outlets, generate demand for fish and seafood products from wholesalers. When demand from these venues rises, wholesalers benefit. Increased demand for food services and drinking places represents a potential opportunity for the industry. Wholesalers in the seafood industry stand to gain as consumer preferences shift toward dining out and convenience.

The canned fish product segment has become less popular than fresh or frozen fish. Most people prefer buying fresh fish for its superior taste and quality, while others opt for frozen fish, which offers convenience without sacrificing much quality.

business_locations.location_description: In the Western United States, Alaska and California are the main hubs for the fishing industry and are heavily involved in fishing and seafood processing. These states significantly dominate catch volumes resulting from their rich marine ecosystems. The thriving fishing industries in Alaska and California boost related businesses, establishing this region as a crucial center for the country's fishery sector and contributing substantially to the economy.

With its access to large bodies of water, the Southeast region of the United States benefits from abundant marine resources. Florida and Louisiana are key contributors, significantly impacting catch volumes. The coastal positioning of the Southeast states enables high-yield fishing and marine farming, which play a critical role in the region's economic activity related to fish and seafood wholesaling.

The mid-Atlantic region of the United States is uniquely positioned to harvest marine resources, bordered by the expansive Atlantic Ocean and the vast Great Lakes. This geographic advantage facilitates extensive marine exploitation. The mid-Atlantic region specializes in harvesting species from the Great Lakes, like trout, salmon and walleye. It benefits from a rich ecological zone, and advanced fishing techniques ensure a thriving and robust fishing industry.

Fishing in the North Atlantic, notably New England, Massachusetts, Maine and Rhode Island, is renowned for its high-quality and abundant crab harvests. This region's industry is synonymous with premium crab production. Integral to the regional economy, the fishing industry in these states constitutes a significant portion of local businesses. Globally recognized for exceptional crabs, it substantially contributes to the area's sustainability and economic growth.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA oversees food manufacturing and storage, establishing specific identity standards for certain foods to guarantee quality and consistency. The agency also dictates the format and essential content for food labeling to ensure that consumers have access to clear and accurate nutritional information. In essence, it forms the cornerstone of food safety and information regulations.

This regulation mandates strict control of seafood methylmercury levels to protect public health, with a particular focus on pregnant women, infants, and children. It sets a specific tolerance level, superseding previous FDA regulations, that must be rigorously adhered to. Continuous monitoring of mercury levels in seafood is compulsory to ensure consumer safety.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Regulatory compliance presents a significant barrier, as wholesalers must navigate complex food safety standards, environmental regulations and import/export laws, all of which require thorough knowledge and can be costly.

High initial capital requirements, including the purchase of specialized equipment, cold storage facilities and inventory, create a substantial barrier for new entrants attempting to establish a competitive operation.

Establishing a unique value proposition is challenging due to seafood's commoditized nature. This makes it difficult for new entrants to stand out in a market dominated by established wholesalers with strong relationships.

The fish and seafood wholesaling industry is labor-intensive, requiring skilled workers for processing, handling and distribution, which can be a barrier for new businesses struggling to attract and retain experienced labor.

basis_points.basis_description: The primary competing industries include beef, pork, egg and poultry wholesaling. Each of these commodities offers a good substitute for protein found in seafood.
General line grocery merchant wholesalers are a significant source of external competition. They move a sizeable portion of seafood each year.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Low barriers to entry give way to smaller wholesalers
concentration_points.concentration_description: Most wholesalers distribute limited quantities of fish and seafood to local or regional retail stores, seafood processors, or smaller wholesalers. They operate mainly from small warehouses near aquaculture farms or fishing ports.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Geography limits the expansion of businesses
concentration_points.concentration_description: The prevalence of small businesses in this industry indicates many companies operating within confined geographical regions, often limited to city or regional boundaries, which creates intense local competition.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase expenses for fish and seafood companies are typically higher than the overall wholesaling sector's average. The perishable nature of seafood and the challenges of consistently securing natural inputs contribute to these elevated costs. Rising fuel prices and hiking seafood prices have marginally driven up purchase costs. These factors have significantly impacted the overall expenses within the fish and seafood wholesaling industry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The fish and seafood wholesaling industry is labor-intensive, requiring skilled workers for processing, handling and distribution, which can be a barrier for new businesses struggling to attract and retain experienced labor.

volatility_points.volatility_description: - Natural events like storms, overfishing or regulatory changes can drastically influence supply, leading to price spikes or shortages that directly impact revenue. - The availability of cheaper imports can undercut domestic prices, forcing wholesalers to adjust their pricing strategies frequently, contributing to revenue swings. - Consumer preferences for seafood can shift rapidly because of health trends, sustainability concerns, or economic conditions, leading to unpredictable sales and revenue.

- Many seafood species are only available during certain times of the year, leading to periods of high revenue followed by low or no revenue, creating volatility. - Climate change and pollution impact fish populations and their habitats, leading to unpredictable supply levels that can cause sudden revenue drops or surges. - Environmental regulations, like fishing quotas and restrictions, can change suddenly, disrupting supply and causing significant revenue fluctuations for wholesalers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: TECH-DRIVEN TRACEABILITY ENHANCING SUPPLY CHAIN TRANSPARENCY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Blockchain technology is revolutionizing traceability. It allows wholesalers to verify the origin and handling of seafood from catch to consumer, ensuring authenticity and sustainability. Enhanced transparency builds consumer confidence as buyers increasingly demand proof of sustainable practices and quality standards.

Robotics and automation in seafood processing reduce labor costs and strengthen efficiency, allowing for faster and more consistent product handling. Advanced automation systems enhance quality control by minimizing human error and ensuring precise processing, which improves product consistency.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge in such a crowded industry?
FAQs.answer: The fragmented nature of this industry creates regional operations, which compete mostly on price. Wholesalers that engage in long-term supply contracts will offer better prices.

FAQs.question: How does your company contend with seasonal demand from retail channels?
FAQs.answer: Certain species of fish are only available during specific seasons. Wholesalers that ship out-of-season fish can charge a premium. Seasonal fish will trade at a premium. Industry operators can increase access to specialty or seasonal fish by buying from aquaculturists.

FAQs.question: How does your company negotiate favorable purchase costs with suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers that engage in long-term supply contracts will have reduced purchase costs. Typically, those who leverage scale economies or bulk purchases will pay less per unit and exhibit wider profit. However, since industry operators have been undercut by ex-vessel sales, their prices compared to catches right off the boat are just not low enough to entice major spikes in demand

FAQs.question: How do you manage volatile demand that results from
FAQs.answer: - Wholesalers that enter into long-term supply contracts will reduce price volatility. - Wholesalers who offer seasonal goods out of season can sell them at a premium.

FAQs.question: How does the role of changing technology impact
FAQs.answer: - Wholesalers that adopt the latest technology will be afforded labor cost savings. - Adopting the latest technology, like electronic inventory management systems, will boost operational efficiency. - This can be particularly crucial during periods of depressed economic activity.

FAQs.question: Does your company use RFID to optimize inventory
FAQs.answer: - Radio frequency identification tags can better track products through the supply chain, ensuring safe delivery and handling. - Radio frequency identification tags are more durable than traditional barcodes.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all relevant health and
FAQs.answer: - Wholesalers with a proven reputation for safety and cleanliness will exhibit higher inventory turnover. - Wholesalers that engage in strong compliance efforts will be favored by public opinion.

FAQs.question: How have you adjusted to new regulations? How have you handled compliance costs?
FAQs.answer: - The US government may put supply quotas in place or ban the fishing of certain species. - The US government has been cracking down on importing illegal seafood, tracking catches step by step through the supply chain.

FAQs.question: What cost-saving measures do you currently employ and what measures might you implement in the future?
FAQs.answer: - Wholesalers that enter into long-term supply contracts will reduce purchase costs. - Aquaculture has the potential to mitigate price volatility.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected your purchase costs and selling prices?
FAQs.answer: - Wholesalers should exhibit declines in purchase costs as the price of seafood declines. - Wholesalers who lock in predetermined rates from suppliers will exhibit reduced purchase costs and wider profit.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts with key end-users? Are you Located close to your target markets and suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Having contacts within key markets Establishing links with various retail and food service outlets ensures a reliable level of demand for wholesale fish and seafood products. Moreover, because of the nature of fish and seafood products, it's infeasible to transport them long distances before spoilage sets in.

FAQs.question: Do you have contracts with reliable input providers?
FAQs.answer: Access to or contracts with upstream supplies like fisheries and processors are key success factors for fish and seafood wholesalers. These contracts also typically include terms to prevent supply chain disruptions and maintain price stability, contributing to the wholesalers' business stability and growth.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain optimum stock levels? What products frequently sell out, and what products are in the least demand?
FAQs.answer: The ability to service clients quickly with the right products and manage inventory is crucial for success in the wholesale industry. By entering into long-term provision contracts, operators can take some of the guesswork out of what will sell next week.

FAQs.question: Has boosted awareness of the nutritional benefits of consuming fish and seafood expanded demand for your products? If not, how can you promote them?
FAQs.answer: Consumer perception concerning the nutritional content of fish and seafood is a crucial determinant of downstream demand for various industry products.

FAQs.question: Price of seafood
FAQs.answer: The domestic price of fish and seafood will influence wholesale volumes. Demand for fish and seafood wholesalers' products tends to fall if the domestic price of fish and seafood strengthens, as higher prices make the products less affordable for some customers. Wholesalers often provide a wide range of fish and seafood products, but whether they sell higher-quality products depends on their source and target market. High-end wholesalers typically offer higher-quality products for upscale restaurants and markets.

FAQs.question: Demand from food services and drinking places
FAQs.answer: Foodservice establishments demand fish and seafood products from wholesalers, often regularly. Fish and seafood wholesalers typically establish long-term supply contracts with food service and drinking places to ensure consistent supply, streamline procurement and establish dependable revenue streams. Wholesalers can expand market reach by offering unique or sustainably sourced products, providing robust delivery networks, ensuring reliable supply chains and maintaining stringent quality standards and certifications.
